description: From Anglo-Norman ordenarie, ordenaire et al., Middle French ordinaire, and their source, Medieval Latin ordinarius, noun use of Latin ōrdinārius (“regular, orderly”), from ōrdō (“order”).

adjectives.description: ordinary (comparative more ordinary, superlative most ordinary)

entries.meaning: (law, of a judge) Having regular jurisdiction; now only used in certain phrases.
Being part of the natural order of things; normal, customary, routine.
examples: On an ordinary day I wake up at nine o'clock, work for six hours, and then go to the gym.

entries.meaning: Having no special characteristics or function; everyday, common, mundane; often deprecatory.
examples: I live a very ordinary life most of the time, but every year I spend a week in Antarctica.
He looked so ordinary, I never thought he'd be capable of murder.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, colloquial, informal) Bad or undesirable.
examples: It was, in some ways a sad, almost pathetic sight to see this great American boat which had fought so hard throughout the cup summer, now looking very ordinary indeed.

definitionGroups.group: A person with authority; authority, ordinance.

entries.meaning: (ecclesiastical, law) A person having immediate jurisdiction in a given case of ecclesiastical law, such as the bishop within a diocese. [from 14th c.]
(obsolete) A courier; someone delivering mail or post. [16th–19th c.]
examples: I  […]  will lay to till you come within hail  […]  but pray respond by the first ordinary.

entries.meaning: (law) A judge with the authority to deal with cases himself or herself rather than by delegation. [from 17th c.]
(now historical) The chaplain of Newgate prison, who prepared condemned prisoners for death. [from 17th c.]
(obsolete) Customary fare, one's regular daily allowance of food; (hence) a regular portion or allowance. [15th–19th c.]
(now chiefly historical) A meal provided for a set price at an eating establishment. [from 16th c.]
examples: Here he recommended me to fix my board, there being an excellent ordinary daily at two o'clock, at which I might dine or not as I pleased.

entries.meaning: (now archaic, historical) A place where such meals are served; a public tavern, inn. [from 16th c.]
examples: He enjoyed a perpetual port duty of fourteen pence a ton, on vessels not owned in the province, yielding not far from five thousand dollars a year; and he exacted a tribute for licenses to hawkers and peddlers and to ordinaries.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) One of the standard geometric designs placed across the center of a coat of arms, such as a pale or fess. [from 16th c.]
An ordinary person or thing; something commonplace. [from 16th c.]
(now Scotland, Ireland) The usual course of things; normal condition or health; a standard way of behaviour or action. [from 16th c.]
(now historical) A penny farthing bicycle. [from 19th c.]
(Christianity) A part of the Christian liturgy that is reasonably constant without regard to the date on which the service is performed.

definitionGroups.group: A book setting out ordinary or regular conduct.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A devotional manual; a book setting our rules for proper conduct. [15th–17th c.]
(Christianity) A rule, or book of rules, prescribing the order of service, especially of Mass. [from 16th c.]
